title: Number of Substrings Containing All Three Characters
description: Given a string s consisting only of characters 'a', 'b', and 'c', find the number of substrings that contain at least one occurrence of each character: 'a', 'b', and 'c'.
aim: Demonstrate variable-size sliding window with character frequency tracking; expand until all three characters are present, then count all valid substrings ending at current position.

examples.explanation: The substrings containing all 'a', 'b', and 'c' are: "abc", "abcb", "abcba", "bcba", "cba".
The substrings containing all 'a', 'b', and 'c' are: "ccab", "ccabc", "ccabcc", "cab", "cabc", "cabcc", "abc", "abcc".

steps.description: Initialize variables. We'll track character frequencies to know when our window contains all three characters.
steps.jarvisMessage: Welcome! We'll use a sliding window to find all substrings containing 'a', 'b', and 'c'. We'll track character frequencies and count valid substrings.
steps.codeBotMessage: We'll expand the window until it contains all three characters, then count all valid substrings ending at the current position.

steps.description: Expand: add 'a'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=0, freq[c]=0. Window doesn't contain all three characters yet.
steps.jarvisMessage: Added 'a'. Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=0, freq[c]=0. Our window doesn't contain all three characters yet, so we can't count any valid substrings.
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "a" is not valid yet. We need 'b' and 'c' to make it valid.

steps.description: Expand: add 'b'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=0. Window still doesn't contain all three characters.
steps.jarvisMessage: Added 'b'. Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=0. Our window still doesn't contain all three characters yet, so we can't count any valid substrings.
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "ab" is not valid yet. We still need 'c' to make it valid.

steps.description: Expand: add 'c'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Window now contains all three characters! Count valid substrings.
steps.jarvisMessage: Added 'c'! Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Our window contains all three characters! We can count valid substrings ending at position 2.
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "abc" is valid! All substrings ending at position 2 are valid: "abc" (length 3), "bc" (length 2), "c" (length 1). Total: 3.

steps.description: Contract: remove 'a'. freq[a]=0, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Window no longer valid, stop contracting.
steps.jarvisMessage: Removed 'a'. Now freq[a]=0, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Our window no longer contains all three characters, so we stop contracting.
steps.codeHint: // Stop contracting when window becomes invalid
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "bc" is not valid anymore. We need 'a' to make it valid again.

steps.description: Expand: add 'b'. freq[a]=0, freq[b]=2, freq[c]=1. Window still doesn't contain all three characters.
steps.jarvisMessage: Added 'b'. Now freq[a]=0, freq[b]=2, freq[c]=1. Our window still doesn't contain all three characters yet, so we can't count any valid substrings.
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "bcb" is not valid yet. We still need 'a' to make it valid.

steps.description: Expand: add 'a'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=2, freq[c]=1. Window now contains all three characters! Count valid substrings.
steps.jarvisMessage: Added 'a'! Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=2, freq[c]=1. Our window contains all three characters again! We can count valid substrings ending at position 4.
steps.codeHint: // Window is valid again, count substrings
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "bcba" is valid! All substrings ending at position 4 are valid: "bcba" (length 4), "cba" (length 3), "ba" (length 2), "a" (length 1). But we already counted some, so we add 1 more.

steps.description: Contract: remove 'b'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Window still valid, continue contracting and counting.
steps.jarvisMessage: Removed 'b'. Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=1. Our window still contains all three characters! We can count more valid substrings ending at position 4.
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "cba" is still valid! All substrings ending at position 4 are valid: "cba" (length 3), "ba" (length 2), "a" (length 1). We add 1 more to our count.

steps.description: Contract: remove 'c'. freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=0. Window no longer valid, stop contracting.
steps.jarvisMessage: Removed 'c'. Now freq[a]=1, freq[b]=1, freq[c]=0. Our window no longer contains all three characters, so we stop contracting.
steps.codeHint: // Stop contracting when window becomes invalid
steps.codeBotMessage: Window "ba" is not valid anymore. We need 'c' to make it valid again.

motivationalMessages: Great thinking! Once the window is valid, all substrings ending at that position are valid.
Exactly! The key insight is to count (n - windowEnd) when the window contains all three characters.
You're mastering substring counting with sliding windows!
Awesome! This technique works for any character frequency problems.

optimal.idea: Use variable-size window with character frequency tracking; expand until all three characters are present, then count all valid substrings ending at current position by adding (n - windowEnd).
walkthrough: Initialize windowStart = 0, count = 0, charFrequency = {a: 0, b: 0, c: 0}.
For windowEnd from 0..n-1, update character frequency.
While window contains all three characters (freq[a] > 0 && freq[b] > 0 && freq[c] > 0):
Add (n - windowEnd) to count (all substrings ending at or after windowEnd are valid).
Shrink window from left (windowStart++), updating freq.
